001package squidpony;
002
003import regexodus.*;
004import squidpony.squidmath.*;
005
006import java.io.Serializable;
007import java.util.ArrayList;
008import java.util.Collection;
009import java.util.Iterator;
010import java.util.Map;

012import static squidpony.Maker.makeList;
013import static squidpony.Maker.makeOM;

015/**
016 * A text processing class that can swap out occurrences of words and replace them with their synonyms.
017 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 5/23/2016.
018 */
019public class Thesaurus implements Serializable{
020    private static final long serialVersionUID = 3387639905758074640L;
021    protected static final Pattern wordMatch = Pattern.compile("([\\pL`]+)"),
022            similarFinder = Pattern.compile(".*?\\b(\\w\\w\\w\\w).*?{\\@1}.*$", "ui");
023    public OrderedMap<CharSequence, GapShuffler<String>> mappings;
024    public ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen.Alteration> alterations = new ArrayList<>(4);
025    public SilkRNG rng;
026    public GapShuffler<String> plantTermShuffler, fruitTermShuffler, nutTermShuffler, flowerTermShuffler;
027    public transient ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen> randomLanguages = new ArrayList<>(2);
028    public transient String latestGenerated = "Nationia";
029    /**
030     * Constructs a new Thesaurus with an unseeded RNG used to shuffle word order.
031     */
032    public Thesaurus()
033    {
034        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
035        rng = new SilkRNG();
036    }
037
038    /**
039     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with the next long from the given RNG.
040     * @param rng an RNG that will only be used to get one long (for seeding this class' RNG)
041     */
042    public Thesaurus(IRNG rng)
043    {
044        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
045        this.rng = new SilkRNG(rng.nextLong());
046    }
047
048    /**
049     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
050     * @param shuffleSeed a long for seeding this class' RNG
051     */
052    public Thesaurus(long shuffleSeed)
053    {
054        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
055        this.rng = new SilkRNG(shuffleSeed);
056    }
057
058
059    /**
060     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
061     * @param shuffleSeed a String for seeding this class' RNG
062     */
063    public Thesaurus(String shuffleSeed)
064    {
065        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
066        this.rng = new SilkRNG(CrossHash.hash64(shuffleSeed));
067    }
068
069    /**
070     * Changes the sequences for all groups of synonyms this can produce, effectively turning this Thesaurus into a
071     * different version that knows all the same synonyms and categories but will produce different results.
072     * @param state any long; will be given to {@link SilkRNG#setState(long)}
073     */
074    public void refresh(long state)
075    {
076        refresh((int)(state & 0xFFFFFFFFL), (int)(state >>> 32));
077    }
078
079    /**
080     * Changes the sequences for all groups of synonyms this can produce, effectively turning this Thesaurus into a
081     * different version that knows all the same synonyms and categories but will produce different results.
082     * @param stateA any int; the first part of the state of a {@link SilkRNG}
083     * @param stateB any int; the second part of the state of a {@link SilkRNG}
084     */
085    public void refresh(int stateA, int stateB)
086    {
087        this.rng.setState(stateA, stateB);
088        final int sz = mappings.size();
089        for (int i = 0; i < sz; i++) {
090            mappings.getAt(i).setRNG(rng, true);
091        }
092        plantTermShuffler.setRNG(rng, true);
093        fruitTermShuffler.setRNG(rng, true);
094        nutTermShuffler.setRNG(rng, true);
095        flowerTermShuffler.setRNG(rng, true);
096    }
097    
098    /**
099     * Allows this Thesaurus to find the exact words in synonyms and, when requested, replace each occurrence with a
100     * different word from the same Collection. Each word in synonyms should have the same part of speech, so "demon"
101     * and "devils" should not be in the same list of synonyms (singular noun and plural noun), but "demon" and "devil"
102     * could be (each is a singular noun). The Strings in synonyms should all be lower-case, since case is picked up
103     * from the text as it is being replaced and not from the words themselves. Proper nouns should normally not be used
104     * as synonyms, since this could get very confusing if it changed occurrences of "Germany" to "France" at random and
105     * a character's name, like "Dorothy", to "Anne", "Emily", "Cynthia", etc. in the middle of a section about Dorothy.
106     * The word matching pattern this uses only matches all-letter words, not words that contain hyphens, apostrophes,
107     * or other punctuation.
108     * @param synonyms a Collection of lower-case Strings with similar meaning and the same part of speech
109     * @return this for chaining
110     */
111    public Thesaurus addSynonyms(Collection<String> synonyms)
112    {
113        if(synonyms.isEmpty())
114            return this;
115        //long prevState = rng.getState();
116        //rng.setState(prevState ^ CrossHash.hash64(synonyms));
117        GapShuffler<String> shuffler = new GapShuffler<>(synonyms, rng, true);
118        for(String syn : synonyms)
119        {
120            mappings.put(syn, shuffler);
121        }
122        //rng.setState(prevState);
123        return this;
124    }
125
126    public Thesaurus addReplacement(CharSequence before, String after)
127    {
128        mappings.put(before, new GapShuffler<>(after));
129        return this;
130    }
131
132    /**
133     * Allows this Thesaurus to replace a specific keyword, typically containing multiple backtick characters ('`') so
134     * it can't be confused with a "real word," with one of the words in synonyms (chosen in shuffled order). The
135     * backtick is the only punctuation character that this class' word matcher considers part of a word, both for this
136     * reason and because it is rarely used in English text.
137     * @param keyword a word (typically containing backticks, '`') that will be replaced by a word from synonyms
138     * @param synonyms a Collection of lower-case Strings with similar meaning and the same part of speech
139     * @return this for chaining
140     */
141    public Thesaurus addCategory(String keyword, Collection<String> synonyms)
142    {
143        if(synonyms.isEmpty())
144            return this;
145        //long prevState = rng.getState();
146        //rng.setState(prevState ^ CrossHash.hash64(synonyms));
147        GapShuffler<String> shuffler = new GapShuffler<>(synonyms, rng, true);
148        mappings.put(keyword, shuffler);
149        //rng.setState(prevState);
150        return this;
151    }
152
153    /**
154     * Adds several pre-made categories to this Thesaurus' known categories, but won't cause it to try to replace normal
155     * words with synonyms (only categories, which contain backticks in the name). The keywords this currently knows,
156     * and the words it will replace those keywords with, are:
157     * <br>
158     * (THIS IS OUT OF DATE, THERE ARE MORE KNOWN.)
159     * <br>
160     * <ul>
161     *     <li>"calm`adj`": harmonious, peaceful, pleasant, serene, placid, tranquil, calm</li>
162     *     <li>"calm`noun`": harmony, peace, kindness, serenity, tranquility, calm</li>
163     *     <li>"org`noun`": fraternity, brotherhood, order, group, foundation, association, guild, fellowship, partnership</li>
164     *     <li>"org`nouns`": fraternities, brotherhoods, orders, groups, foundations, associations, guilds, fellowships, partnerships</li>
165     *     <li>"empire`adj`": imperial, prince's, king's, sultan's, regal, dynastic, royal, hegemonic, monarchic, ascendant, emir's, lordly</li>
166     *     <li>"empire`noun`": empire, emirate, kingdom, sultanate, dominion, dynasty, imperium, hegemony, triumvirate, ascendancy, monarchy, commonwealth</li>
167     *     <li>"empire`nouns`": empires, emirates, kingdoms, sultanates, dominions, dynasties, imperia, hegemonies, triumvirates, ascendancies, monarchies, commonwealths</li>
168     *     <li>"union`adj`": united, allied, people's, confederated, federated, congressional, independent, associated, unified, democratic</li>
169     *     <li>"union`noun`": union, alliance, coalition, confederation, federation, congress, confederacy, league, faction, republic</li>
170     *     <li>"union`nouns`": unions, alliances, coalitions, confederations, federations, congresses, confederacies, leagues, factions, republics</li>
171     *     <li>"militia`noun`": rebellion, resistance, militia, liberators, warriors, fighters, militants, front, irregulars</li>
172     *     <li>"militia`nouns`": rebellions, resistances, militias, liberators, warriors, fighters, militants, fronts, irregulars</li>
173     *     <li>"gang`noun`": gang, syndicate, mob, crew, posse, mafia, cartel</li>
174     *     <li>"gang`nouns`": gangs, syndicates, mobs, crews, posses, mafias, cartels</li>
175     *     <li>"duke`noun`": duke, earl, baron, fief, lord, shogun</li>
176     *     <li>"duke`nouns`": dukes, earls, barons, fiefs, lords, shoguns</li>
177     *     <li>"duchy`noun`": duchy, earldom, barony, fiefdom, lordship, shogunate</li>
178     *     <li>"duchy`nouns`": duchies, earldoms, baronies, fiefdoms, lordships, shogunates</li>
179     *     <li>"magical`adj`": arcane, enchanted, sorcerous, ensorcelled, magical, mystical</li>
180     *     <li>"holy`adj`": auspicious, divine, holy, sacred, prophetic, blessed, godly</li>
181     *     <li>"unholy`adj`": bewitched, occult, unholy, macabre, accursed, profane, vile</li>
182     *     <li>"forest`adj`": natural, primal, verdant, lush, fertile, bountiful</li>
183     *     <li>"forest`noun`": nature, forest, greenery, jungle, woodland, grove, copse</li>
184     *     <li>"fancy`adj`": grand, glorious, magnificent, magnanimous, majestic, great, powerful</li>
185     *     <li>"evil`adj`": heinous, scurrilous, terrible, horrible, debased, wicked, evil, malevolent, nefarious, vile</li>
186     *     <li>"good`adj`": righteous, moral, good, pure, compassionate, flawless, perfect</li>
187     *     <li>"sinister`adj`": shadowy, silent, lethal, deadly, fatal, venomous, cutthroat, murderous, bloodstained, stalking</li>
188     *     <li>"sinister`noun`": shadow, silence, assassin, ninja, venom, poison, snake, murder, blood, razor, tiger</li>
189     *     <li>"blade`noun`": blade, knife, sword, axe, stiletto, katana, scimitar, hatchet, spear, glaive, halberd,
190     *               hammer, maul, flail, mace, sickle, scythe, whip, lance, nunchaku, saber, cutlass, trident</li>
191     *     <li>"bow`noun`": bow, longbow, shortbow, crossbow, sling, atlatl, bolas, javelin, net, shuriken, dagger</li>
192     *     <li>"weapon`noun`": blade, knife, sword, axe, stiletto, katana, scimitar, hatchet, spear, glaive, halberd,
193     *               hammer, maul, flail, mace, sickle, scythe, whip, lance, nunchaku, saber, cutlass, trident,
194     *               bow, longbow, shortbow, crossbow, sling, atlatl, bolas, javelin, net, shuriken, dagger</li>
195     *     <li>"musket`noun`": arquebus, blunderbuss, musket, matchlock, flintlock, wheellock, cannon</li>
196     *     <li>"grenade`noun`": rocket, grenade, missile, bomb, warhead, explosive, flamethrower</li>
197     *     <li>"rifle`noun`": pistol, rifle, handgun, firearm, longarm, shotgun</li>
198     *     <li>"blade`nouns`": blades, knives, swords, axes, stilettos, katana, scimitars, hatchets, spears, glaives, halberds,
199     *               hammers, mauls, flails, maces, sickles, scythes, whips, lances, nunchaku, sabers, cutlasses, tridents</li>
200     *     <li>"bow`nouns`": bows, longbows, shortbows, crossbows, slings, atlatls, bolases, javelins, nets, shuriken, daggers</li>
201     *     <li>"weapon`nouns`": blades, knives, swords, axes, stilettos, katana, scimitars, hatchets, spears, glaives, halberds,
202     *               hammers, mauls, flails, maces, sickles, scythes, whips, lances, nunchaku, sabers, cutlasses, tridents,
203     *               bows, longbows, shortbows, crossbows, slings, atlatls, bolases, javelins, nets, shuriken, daggers</li>
204     *     <li>"musket`nouns`": arquebusses, blunderbusses, muskets, matchlocks, flintlocks, wheellocks, cannons</li>
205     *     <li>"grenade`nouns`": rockets, grenades, missiles, bombs, warheads, explosives, flamethrowers</li>
206     *     <li>"rifle`nouns`": pistols, rifles, handguns, firearms, longarms, shotguns</li>
207     *     <li>"tech`adj`": cyber, digital, electronic, techno, hacker, crypto, turbo, mechanical, servo</li>
208     *     <li>"sole`adj`": sole, true, singular, total, ultimate, final, last</li>
209     *     <li>"light`adj`": bright, glowing, solar, stellar, lunar, radiant, luminous, shimmering</li>
210     *     <li>"light`noun`": light, glow, sun, star, moon, radiance, dawn, torch</li>
211     *     <li>"light`nouns`": lights, glimmers, suns, stars, moons, torches</li>
212     *     <li>"smart`adj`": brilliant, smart, genius, wise, clever, cunning, mindful, aware</li>
213     *     <li>"smart`noun`": genius, wisdom, cunning, awareness, mindfulness, acumen, smarts, knowledge</li>
214     *     <li>"bandit`noun`": thief, raider, bandit, rogue, brigand, highwayman, pirate</li>
215     *     <li>"bandit`nouns`": thieves, raiders, bandits, rogues, brigands, highwaymen, pirates</li>
216     *     <li>"guard`noun`": protector, guardian, warden, defender, guard, shield, sentinel, watchman, knight</li>
217     *     <li>"guard`nouns`": protectors, guardians, wardens, defenders, guards, shields, sentinels, watchmen, knights</li>
218     *     <li>"rage`noun`": rage, fury, anger, wrath, frenzy, vengeance</li>
219     * </ul>
220     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
221     * first letter of the produced fake word. Capitalizing the second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake
222     * word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it won't change the internally-stored list of words.
223     * @return this for chaining
224     */
225    public Thesaurus addKnownCategories()
226    {
227        for(Map.Entry<String, ArrayList<String>> kv : categories.entrySet())
228        {
229            addCategory(kv.getKey(), kv.getValue());
230        }
231        plantTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(plantTerms, rng, true);
232        fruitTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(fruitTerms, rng, true);
233        nutTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(nutTerms, rng, true);
234        flowerTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(flowerTerms, rng, true);
235        return this;
236    }

238    /**
239     * Adds a large list of words pre-generated by FakeLanguageGen and hand-picked for fitness, and makes them
240     * accessible with a keyword based on the language and any tweaks made to it. The keywords this currently knows:
241     * <br>
242     * <ul>
243     *     <li>"jp`gen`": Imitation Japanese</li>
244     *     <li>"fr`gen`": Imitation French; contains some accented chars</li>
245     *     <li>"gr`gen`": Imitation Greek (romanized)</li>
246     *     <li>"ru`gen`": Imitation Russian (romanized)</li>
247     *     <li>"sw`gen`": Imitation Swahili</li>
248     *     <li>"so`gen`": Imitation Somali</li>
249     *     <li>"en`gen`": Imitation English (not very good on its own)</li>
250     *     <li>"ar`gen`": Imitation Arabic (better); doesn't have accents and should be more readable</li>
251     *     <li>"nr`gen`": Imitation Old Norse (using simpler and easier-to-pronounce spelling)</li>
252     *     <li>"nr`acc`gen`": Imitation Old Norse (using the uncommon letters used in modern Icelandic)</li>
253     *     <li>"hi`gen`": Imitation Hindi (romanized and with accents removed)</li>
254     *     <li>"kr`gen`": Imitation Korean (romanized)</li>
255     *     <li>"na`gen`": Imitation Nahuatl (spelled like how Spanish loanwords from Nahuatl are spelled)</li>
256     *     <li>"mn`gen`": Imitation Mongolian (the form of the language from medieval times, romanized)</li>
257     *     <li>"in`gen`": Imitation Inuktitut (romanized)</li>
258     *     <li>"si`gen`": "Simplish" (simplified imitation English, without special word endings like "-ight")</li>
259     *     <li>"fn`gen`": Fantasy Names; styled after the possibly-Europe-like names common in fantasy books</li>
260     *     <li>"fn`acc`gen`": Fancy Fantasy Names; the same as "fn`gen`", but with lots of accented chars</li>
261     *     <li>"lc`gen`": Lovecraft; styled after the names of creatures from H.P. Lovecraft's Cthulhu Mythos</li>
262     *     <li>"el`gen`": Elf, modeled after J.R.R. Tolkien's languages for elves</li>
263     *     <li>"gb`gen`": Goblin, fantasy language of sneaky species</li>
264     *     <li>"if`gen`": Infernal, fantasy language of clever and subtle fiends</li>
265     *     <li>"dm`gen`": Demonic, fantasy language of brutish fiends</li>
266     *     <li>"al`a`gen`": Alien A, fantasy language with very unusual consonants</li>
267     *     <li>"al`e`gen`": Alien E, fantasy language with click sounds but no "lip sounds"</li>
268     *     <li>"al`i`gen`": Alien I, fantasy language with many tones and "liquid sounds"</li>
269     *     <li>"al`o`gen`": Alien O, fantasy language with long words and lengthy vowel clusters</li>
270     *     <li>"al`u`gen`": Alien U, fantasy language with many accented consonants and different suffixes</li>
271     *     <li>"ru`so`gen`": Mix of imitation Russian (75%) and Somali (25%)</li>
272     *     <li>"gr`hi`gen`": Mix of imitation Greek (50%) and Hindi (accents removed, 50%)</li>
273     *     <li>"sw`fr`gen`": Mix of imitation Swahili (70%) and French (30%)</li>
274     *     <li>"ar`jp`gen`": Mix of imitation Arabic (accents removed, 60%) and Japanese (40%)</li>
275     *     <li>"sw`gr`gen`": Mix of imitation Swahili (60%) and Greek (40%)</li>
276     *     <li>"gr`so`gen`": Mix of imitation Greek (60%) and Somali (40%)</li>
277     *     <li>"en`hi`gen`": Mix of imitation English (60%) and Hindi (accents removed, 40%)</li>
278     *     <li>"en`jp`gen`": Mix of imitation English (60%) and Japanese (40%)</li>
279     *     <li>"so`hi`gen`": Mix of imitation Somali (60%) and Hindi (accents removed, 40%)</li>
280     *     <li>"ru`gr`gen`": Mix of imitation Russian (60%) and Greek (40%)</li>
281     *     <li>"lc`gr`gen`": Mix of Lovecraft-styled names (60%) and imitation Russian (40%)</li>
282     *     <li>"fr`mod`gen`": Imitation French; modified to replace doubled consonants like "gg" with "gsh" or similar</li>
283     *     <li>"jp`mod`gen`": Imitation Japanese; modified to sometimes double vowels from "a" to "aa" or similar</li>
284     *     <li>"so`mod`gen`": Imitation Somali (not really); modified beyond recognition and contains accents</li>
285     * </ul>
286     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
287     * first letter of the produced fake word, which is often desirable for things like place names. Capitalizing the
288     * second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it
289     * won't change the internally-stored list of words.
290     * @return this for chaining
291     */
292    public Thesaurus addFakeWords()
293    {
294        //long state = rng.getState();
295        for(Map.Entry<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen> kv : languages.entrySet())
296        {
297            ArrayList<String> words = new ArrayList<>(16);
298            for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++) {
299                words.add(kv.getValue().word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
300            }
301            addCategory(StringKit.replace(kv.getKey(), "gen", "pre"), words);
302        }
303        //rng.setState(state);
304        return this;
305    }
306
307    private StringBuilder modify(CharSequence text)
308    {
309        Matcher m;
310        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(text);
311        Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer tb, working = Replacer.wrap(sb);
312        StringBuilder tmp;
313        boolean found;
314        FakeLanguageGen.Alteration alt;
315        for (int a = 0; a < alterations.size(); a++) {
316            alt = alterations.get(a);
317            tmp = working.sb;
318            tb = Replacer.wrap(new StringBuilder(tmp.length()));
319            m = alt.replacer.getPattern().matcher(tmp);
320
321            found = false;
322            while (true) {
323                if (rng.nextDouble() < alt.chance) {
324                    if (!Replacer.replaceStep(m, alt.replacer.getSubstitution(), tb))
325                        break;
326                    found = true;
327                } else {
328                    if (!m.find())
329                        break;
330                    found = true;
331                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, tb);
332                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.MATCH, tb);
333                    m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
334                }
335            }
336            if (found) {
337                m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, tb);
338                working = tb;
339            }
340        }
341        return working.sb;
342
343    }
344    /**
345     * Given a String, StringBuilder, or other CharSequence that should contain words this knows synonyms for, this
346     * replaces each occurrence of such a known word with one of its synonyms, leaving unknown words untouched. Words
347     * that were learned together as synonyms with addSynonyms() will be replaced in such a way that an individual
348     * replacement word should not occur too close to a previous occurrence of the same word; that is, replacing the
349     * text "You fiend! You demon! You despoiler of creation; devil made flesh!", where "fiend", "demon", and "devil"
350     * are all synonyms, would never produce a string that contained "fiend" as the replacement for all three of those.
351     * @param text a CharSequence, such as a String, that contains words in the source language
352     * @return a String of the translated text.
353     */
354    public String process(CharSequence text)
355    {
356        Replacer rep = wordMatch.replacer(new SynonymSubstitution());
357        if(alterations.isEmpty())
358            return rep.replace(text);
359        else
360            return modify(rep.replace(text)).toString();
361    }
362
363    public String lookup(String word)
364    {
365        if(word.isEmpty())
366            return word;
367        String word2 = word.toLowerCase();
368        if(mappings.containsKey(word2))
369        {
370            String nx = mappings.get(word2).next();
371            if(nx.isEmpty())
372                return nx;
373            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
374                return nx.toUpperCase();
375            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
376            {
377                return Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)) + nx.substring(1);
378            }
379            return nx;
380        }
381        else if(languages.containsKey(word2))
382        {
383            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
384                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase();
385            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
386            {
387                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4));
388            }
389            return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4));
390        }
391        return word;
392    }
393
394    private class SynonymSubstitution implements Substitution
395    {
396        private StringBuilder temp = new StringBuilder(64);
397        @Override
398        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
399            //dest.append(lookup(match.group(0)));
400            temp.setLength(0);
401            match.getGroup(0, temp);
402            writeLookup(dest, temp);
403        }
404    }
405
406    private void writeLookup(TextBuffer dest, StringBuilder word) {
407        if(word.length() <= 0)
408            return;
409        if(mappings.containsKey(word))
410        {
411            String nx = mappings.get(word).next();
412            if(nx.isEmpty())
413                return;
414            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
415            {
416                dest.append(nx.toUpperCase());
417                return;
418            }
419            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
420            {
421                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)));
422                dest.append(nx.substring(1));
423                return;
424            }
425            dest.append(nx);
426            return;
427        }
428        else if(languages.containsKey(word))
429        {
430            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
431            {
432                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase());
433            }
434            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
435            {
436                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4)));
437            }
438            else
439            {
440                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
441            }
442            return;
443        }
444        else if(numbers.containsKey(word))
445        {
446            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
447            {
448                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)).toUpperCase());
449            }
450            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
451            {
452                String w = numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word));
453                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
454                dest.append(w.substring(1));
455            }
456            else
457            {
458                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)));
459            }
460            return;
461        }
462        else if(numberAdjectives.containsKey(word))
463        {
464            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
465            {
466                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)).toUpperCase());
467            }
468            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
469            {
470                String w = numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word));
471                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
472                dest.append(w.substring(1));
473            }
474            else
475            {
476                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)));
477            }
478            return;
479        }
480        if(dest instanceof Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)
481        {
482            ((Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)dest).sb.append(word);
483        }
484        else
485            dest.append(word.toString());
486
487    }
488
489    private class RandomLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
490    {
491        @Override
492        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
493            FakeLanguageGen lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
494            randomLanguages.add(lang);
495            if(match.isCaptured(1))
496            {
497                lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
498                randomLanguages.add(lang);
499                do {
500                    latestGenerated = randomLanguages.get(0).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)))
501                            + "-" + randomLanguages.get(1).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
502                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
503                dest.append(latestGenerated);
504            }
505            else
506            {
507                do{
508                    latestGenerated = lang.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
509                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
510                dest.append(latestGenerated);
511            }
512        }
513    }
514
515    private class KnownLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
516    {
517        public FakeLanguageGen language;
518        public KnownLanguageSubstitution(FakeLanguageGen lang)
519        {
520            language = lang;
521        }
522        @Override
523        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
524            if (match.isCaptured(1)) {
525                do
526                {
527                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5))) +
528                            "-" + language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
529                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
530                dest.append(latestGenerated);
531            } else
532            {
533                do{
534                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
535                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
536                dest.append(latestGenerated);
537            }
538        }
539    }
540
541    /**
542     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth".
543     * Needs {@link #addKnownCategories()} to be called on this Thesaurus first. May use accented characters, as in
544     * "Thùdshù-Hyóttiálb Hegemony" or "The Glorious Chô Empire"; if you want to strip these out and replace accented
545     * chars with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
546     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
547     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making nation names, by
548     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
549     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the nation name, like "Drayo" in
550     * "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". If more than one language was used in the nation name, as in "Thùdshù-Hyóttiálb
551     * Hegemony", you will have two languages in randomLanguages, so here "Thùdshù" would be generated by the first
552     * language, and "Hyóttiálb" by the second language. Calling this method replaces the current contents of
553     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can. This also assigns the
554     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
555     * "The Glorious Chô Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Chô" at the same time the longer name
556     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
557     *
558     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
559     */
560    public String makeNationName()
561    {
562        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
563        int frustration = 0;
564        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
565            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
566        randomLanguages.clear();
567        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
568        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
569        return replacer.replace(working);
570    }
571    /**
572     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth",
573     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. Needs {@link #addKnownCategories()} to be
574     * called on this Thesaurus first. May use accented characters, as in "Thùdshù Hegemony" or "The Glorious Chô
575     * Empire", if the given language can produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars
576     * with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
577     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
578     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this. This assigns the
579     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
580     * "The Glorious Chô Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Chô" at the same time the longer name
581     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
582     * <br>
583     * Some nation names use a hyphenated pairing of what would normally be names in two different languages; if one of
584     * those names is produced by this it will produce two names in the same linguistic style. The randomLanguages field
585     * is not populated by this method; it is assumed that since you are passing this a FakeLanguageGen, you already
586     * have the one you want to use anyway.
587     *
588     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
589     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
590     */
591    public String makeNationName(FakeLanguageGen language)
592    {
593        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
594        int frustration = 0;
595        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
596            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
597        randomLanguages.clear();
598        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
599        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
600        return replacer.replace(working);
601    }
602
603    /**
604     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "Ikesheha's maple" or "sugarleaf birch".
605     * Needs {@link #addKnownCategories()} to be called on this Thesaurus first.
606     * called on this Thesaurus first. May use accented characters, as in "Emôa's greenwood", if the given language can
607     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
608     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which returns a CharSequence that can be converted
609     * to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
610     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making names, by
611     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
612     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like
613     * "Drayo" in "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". Calling this method replaces the current contents of
614     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can.
615     *
616     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
617     */
618    public String makePlantName()
619    {
620        if(categories.isEmpty())
621        {
622            addKnownCategories();
623        }
624        if(plantTermShuffler == null)
625        {
626            plantTermShuffler = new GapShuffler<>(plantTerms, rng, true);
627        }
628        String working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
629        int frustration = 0;
630        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
631            working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
632        randomLanguages.clear();
633        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
634        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
635        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
636    }

835    /**

839     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you

866
867    /**
868     * Gets an English word for a given number, if this knows it. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20
869     * ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers. If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a
870     * String, such as "537" or "-1".
871     * @param number the number to get a word for
872     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)}.
873     */
874    public static String numberWord(final int number)
875    {
876        switch (number){
877            case 0: return "zero";
878            case 1: return "one";
879            case 2: return "two";
880            case 3: return "three";
881            case 4: return "four";
882            case 5: return "five";
883            case 6: return "six";
884            case 7: return "seven";
885            case 8: return "eight";
886            case 9: return "nine";
887            case 10: return "ten";
888            case 11: return "eleven";
889            case 12: return "twelve";
890            case 13: return "thirteen";
891            case 14: return "fourteen";
892            case 15: return "fifteen";
893            case 16: return "sixteen";
894            case 17: return "seventeen";
895            case 18: return "eighteen";
896            case 19: return "nineteen";
897            case 20: return "twenty";
898            case 30: return "thirty";
899            case 40: return "fourty";
900            case 50: return "fifty";
901            case 60: return "sixty";
902            case 70: return "seventy";
903            case 80: return "eighty";
904            case 90: return "ninety";
905            case 100: return "hundred";
906            case 1000: return "thousand";
907            case 1000000: return "million";
908            case 1000000000: return "billion";
909            default: return String.valueOf(number);
910        }
911    }
912
913    /**
914     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
915     * "eleventh"). These words are known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some higher numbers. If a
916     * word isn't known for a number, this appends a suffix based on the last base-10 digit to the number, as with "0th"
917     * or "42nd".
918     * @param number the number to get a position adjective for
919     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)} followed by a two-char suffix from the last digit.
920     */
921    public static String numberAdjective(final int number)
922    {
923        switch (number){
924            case 1: return "first";
925            case 2: return "second";
926            case 3: return "third";
927            case 4: return "fourth";
928            case 5: return "fifth";
929            case 6: return "sixth";
930            case 7: return "seventh";
931            case 8: return "eighth";
932            case 9: return "ninth";
933            case 10: return "tenth";
934            case 11: return "eleventh";
935            case 12: return "twelfth";
936            case 13: return "thirteenth";
937            case 14: return "fourteenth";
938            case 15: return "fifteenth";
939            case 16: return "sixteenth";
940            case 17: return "seventeenth";
941            case 18: return "eighteenth";
942            case 19: return "nineteenth";
943            case 20: return "twentieth";
944            case 30: return "thirtieth";
945            case 40: return "fourtieth";
946            case 50: return "fiftieth";
947            case 60: return "sixtieth";
948            case 70: return "seventieth";
949            case 80: return "eightieth";
950            case 90: return "ninetieth";
951            case 100: return "hundredth";
952            case 1000: return "thousandth";
953            case 1000000: return "millionth";
954            case 1000000000: return "billionth";
955            default: 
956            {
957                switch (number % 10){
958                    case 1: return number + "st";
959                    case 2: return number + "nd";
960                    case 3: return number + "rd";
961                    default:return number + "th";
962                }
963            }
964        }
965    }
966
967    /**
968     * Gets an English word for a number, if this knows it, where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and
969     * highest, both inclusive. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20 ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers.
970     * If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a String, such as "537" or "-1".
971     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
972     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
973     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "six" or "eleven", if it is known
974     */
975    public String numberWordInRange(int lowest, int highest)
976    {
977        return numberWord(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
978    }
979    /**
980     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
981     * "eleventh"), where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and highest, both inclusive. These words are
982     * known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some output for other numbers (such as "42nd" or "23rd").
983     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
984     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
985     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "third" or "twelfth", if it is known
986     */
987    public String numberAdjectiveInRange(int lowest, int highest)
988    {
989        return numberAdjective(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
990    }

1476    /**
1477     * Thesaurus preset that changes all text to sound like this speaker: "Desaurus preset dat changez all text to sound
1478     * like dis speakah." You may be familiar with a certain sci-fi game that has orks who sound like this.
1479     */
1480    public static Thesaurus ORK = new Thesaurus("WAAAAAGH!");
1481    static {
1482        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("\\bth", "d"));
1483        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("th", "dd"));
1484        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("er\\b", "ah"));
1485        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("es\\b", "ez"));
1486        ORK.addReplacement("the", "da")
1487                .addReplacement("their", "deyr")
1488                .addReplacement("yes", "ya")
1489                .addReplacement("your", "youse")
1490                .addReplacement("yours", "youses")
1491                .addReplacement("going", "gon'")
1492                .addReplacement("and", "an'")
1493                .addReplacement("to", "*snort*")
1494                .addReplacement("rhythm", "riddim")
1495                .addReplacement("get", "git")
1496                .addReplacement("good", "gud");
1497        Iterator<String> it = adjective.keySet().iterator();
1498        while (it.hasNext()){
1499            if(!it.next().contains("`adj`"))
1500                it.remove();
1501        }
1502        it = noun.keySet().iterator();
1503        while (it.hasNext()){
1504            if(!it.next().contains("`noun`"))
1505                it.remove();
1506        }
1507        it = nouns.keySet().iterator();
1508        while (it.hasNext()){
1509            if(!it.next().contains("`nouns`"))
1510                it.remove();
1511        }
1512
1513
1514    }
